translated: The Wise Man of the Jar

original: “Uṭṭhehi kaṇha kiṁ sesi,🔽Ko attho supanena te;
analyzed: uṭṭhehi kaṇha kim sesi  kaḥ atthaḥ supanena te
translated: “Rise up, Blackie, why do you sleep?🔽What is the use of sleeping?
the winds are stronger for him,
He rose up in a hurry,
who will bring you a rabbit?”
made of iron, made of silver;
I will make you a rabbit.”
in the forest, in the jungle;
I will bring them to you,
what kind of rabbit do you want?”
the rabbits that are on the earth;
I want a rabbit from the moon,

original: taṁ me ohara kesava”.🔽“So nūna madhuraṁ ñāti,
analyzed: tam me ohara kesava  saḥ nūna madhuram ñāti
translated: take it down for me, Kesava.”🔽“Surely you will give up your sweet life,
You seek what is not to be found,
you desire the moon from the sky.”
Why do you still grieve today
for your son who died long ago?”
“What cannot be obtained by a human,
how can that which cannot be obtained be obtained?
O Kanha, it is not possible to bring back
the one who has died and is mourned.”
as the wise Ghaṭīkāra has today,

original: ghaṭo purisapaṇḍito.🔽Ādittaṁ vata maṁ santaṁ,🔽ghatasittaṁva pāvakaṁ;
analyzed: ghaṭaḥ purisa paṇḍito  ādittam vata mam santa  pāvaka
translated: having made me understand.🔽As if extinguishing a blazing fire,

analyzed: vārinā viyaḥ osiñca  sabbam nibbāpaye dara
translated: a fire burning with hot embers,

analyzed: abbahī vata me salla  yama asi hadayaḥ sita
translated: you have quenched me with water,🔽and extinguished all my grief.🔽The dart has been pulled out,🔽which was lodged in my heart,

analyzed: yaḥ me soka paretassa  putta sokam apānudi
translated: which for me, overcome with grief,🔽removed the grief of my son.
I am now free from the dart,
I do not grieve or weep,
having heard your words, young man.”
Like Ghaṭa did for his elder brother.”

analyzed: cakkavāka su bhūrisa sotthi ghaṭa uti
